journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Efficiency enhancement in a meso-Wankel compressor with overflow

article-meta.aff: Institute of Refrigeration and Cryogenics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Institute of Refrigeration and Cryogenics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. email: wenwang@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Given current environment protection problems, improvement of energy utilization efficiency is a major focus of compressor research. The presence of high-pressure gas in the clearance volume has an important effect on the efficiency of a Wankel compressor. Overflow pertains to the method that fully utilizes the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume. This method is used in this study, and its effect on the performance of a Wankel compressor is analysed by theoretical and simulation analyses. Compressor performance remains at a high level when the ratio of overflow recess volume to the clearance volume is approximately 2 per cent according to this study. Cooling capacity is improved by about 28 per cent compared with the Wankel compressor without overflow, and the relative deviation between the theoretical and the simulation results is kept within reasonable bounds.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: With the increasing demand for mini- and micro-cooling systems, meso- and micro-Wankel compressors have been drawing increasing attention from researchers because of their unique advantages, including structural simplicity, high efficiency, and low noise. A Wankel compressor is a type of rotary machine, for which subsequent developments in rotary machine technology have some reference. Some achievements in research on the micro-Wankel engine and micro-Wankel compressor include prototype development and experimental research on performance [1–3]. Martinez et al. [4] and Swanger et al. [5] improved the sealing mode of the Wankel engine, after which the sealing efficiency increased by 10–50 per cent. A numerical simulation study of a rotary compressor was presented, and the friction loss and leakage were comprehensively analysed [6, 7]. When the dimensions of a Wankel compressor are decreased, the surface-to-volume ratio becomes larger and the surfaces in relative motion cannot be adequately lubricated as in the normal scale. The influence of leakage and friction loss continuously increases, and the efficiency of a Wankel compressor continuously decreases with gradual decrease in design dimensions [8]. Therefore, strategies for improving the efficiency of Wankel compressors, especially that of meso- and micro-units, are key issues in the miniaturization process of a Wankel compressor.

A Wankel compressor consists of a rotor, cylinder, shaft, a pair of gears, apex seals, and endplates, and three enveloped working chambers. The three chambers independently accomplish one cycle with a certain phase difference; that is, the three chambers are in different stages of a cycle. One of these conditions is that the functions of the exhaust chamber be initiated at the end stage of the exhaust process when those of the other two chambers are in the compression and intake stages. During this time, the gas pressure in the exhaust chamber is significantly higher than that in the compression chamber, and the performance of a Wankel compressor can be considerably improved using overflow. The concept of overflow was presented by Dankwart in 1984 [9]. Overflow is a method in which the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume is fully utilized. It causes the high-pressure gas to flow into the compression chamber through the overflow recesses, thereby substantially enhancing the pressure in the compression chamber, and tremendously decreasing the pressure in the clearance volume. The effect of overflow on Wankel compressor performance is shown in Fig. 1. The sequence 1–2–3–4–1 illustrates the thermal process of a conventional Wankel compressor, and the sequence 1–1″–1′–2′–3–3′–4′–1 refers to the thermal process of a Wankel compressor with overflow recesses (it is called modified Wankel compressor in this article). The rapid change in pressure caused by overflow is shown by sequences 1″–1′and 3–3′. The cylinder displacement (V2′–V3) and the inspiratory capacity (V1–V4′) considerably improve compared with those (V2–V3 and V1–V4) of the conventional Wankel compressor; thus, the performance of a Wankel compressor is also considerably enhanced by overflow. Related theoretical analysis and practical use of overflow in the design of a Wankel compressor have not been discussed in current literature. To this end, the effect of overflow on Wankel compressor performance is analysed through theoretical and simulation analyses. Fig. 1
P–V diagram of the thermal process of a Wankel compressor

The effect of overflow on the performance of a Wankel compressor is examined by theoretical analysis. The simulation of a meso-Wankel compressor with overflow recesses is performed with a dynamic mesh, and rotor movement is controlled by a user-defined function. Under the design conditions given in this article, the effect of the position, width, and depth of the overflow recesses on Wankel compressor performance is analysed by simulation. Finally, the simulation results are compared with the theoretical findings.

sec.title: 2 THEORETICAL ANALYSIS OF OVERFLOW AND ITS EFFECT ON THE PERFORMANCE OF A WANKEL COMPRESSOR
2.1 Overflow of the Wankel compressor
sec.p: The existence of a clearance volume is inevitable in a Wankel compressor because of the rotor and cylinder profiles, the limitation in machining accuracy, and the need for friction reduction.

The thermal process of a conventional Wankel compressor is expressed as the sequence 1–2–3–4–1 (Fig. 1). The gas pressure in the compression chamber gradually increases with decreasing volume; this increase corresponds to the compression process (1–2). The compression process is completed, and the exhaust process (2–3) begins when the gas pressure reaches the point of back pressure; the exhaust process ends when the volume of the exhaust chamber reaches its minimum (that is, the clearance volume). The exhaust valve closes and the high-pressure gas, whose pressure is equal to the back pressure in the clearance volume, initiates the free expansion process. During the expansion process (3–4), the gas pressure continuously decreases with increasing expansion chamber volume until the gas pressure is reduced to intake pressure. Only then can the intake process (4–1) begin.

According to the analysis above, the inspiratory capacity of a conventional Wankel compressor is determined from the volume difference between points 1 and 4. The ideal inspiratory capacity is the difference between V1 and V3. Therefore, the existence of the clearance volume reduces the inspiratory capacity through the difference between V3 and V4. To increase the inspiratory capacity and cylinder displacement, the volume of the expansion chamber at the end of the expansion process (V4) should be as close as possible to the volume at the end of the exhaust process (V3). Two methods that satisfy the aforementioned requirement are adopted: The first is to reduce the clearance volume by modifying the rotor and cylinder profiles thereby improving machining accuracy. The second is to make full use of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume. The room for reduction of the clearance volume of a Wankel compressor is very small when the classic profile equation of the rotor and cylinder, as well as the present machining accuracy, is used as basis. The improvement in performance is limited in such an approach. Therefore, this article adopts overflow to make full use of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume and improve Wankel compressor performance.

The two-dimensional (2D) chart of the modified Wankel compressor is shown in Fig. 2. Chamber V3 functions at the end of the exhaust process, whereas the other two chambers function at the compression (V1) and intake (V2) processes. During this time, the apex seal between the exhaust (V3) and the compression (V1) chambers turns the overflow recess over (Fig. 2(b)). The high-pressure gas in the clearance volume (V3) flows into V1 with the low-pressure gas, causing a rapid decrease in the gas pressure in the clearance volume (3–3′ in Fig. 1), and a considerable increase in the gas pressure in the compression chamber (1″–1′ in Fig. 1). In the ideal case, the overflow recesses are placed on the internal surface of cylinder, and near the apex seal between the compression and exhaust chambers when the latter reaches its minimum volume (Fig. 2). The mixing process is assumed to occur instantaneously. To ensure that overflow is completed in the shortest time possible in satisfying the above-mentioned assumption, the overflow recesses are assumed uniformly spread along the height of the cylinder, and the circular channel is chosen for fluid flow. Therefore, a long and circular channel is adopted in the overflow recess design of the Wankel compressor in this study. The sequence 1–1″–1′–2′–3–3′–4′–1 represents the thermal process of the modified Wankel compressor. Fig. 2
Schematic of the design of the overflow recesses for a Wankel compressor

Volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement are two important parameters in the evaluation of compressor performance. The volumetric efficiency of the compressor can be shown by the ratio of the inspiratory capacity to the swept volume, obtained by the difference between the maximum and minimum volumes of the working chamber. The cylinder displacement of the compressor is calculated by taking the difference between the volume of the compression chamber at the end of the compression process and the volume of the exhaust chamber at the end of the exhaust process.

The volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement of the conventional and modified Wankel compressor are calculated using equations (1) to (4). The detailed derivation is provided in Appendix, and the assumptions:
The flow resistance in the overflow is neglected, which means the overflow is completed instantaneously.
The chocked flow does not happen during overflow
(1) (2) (3) (4) where γ is the compression ratio, γ = P2/P1, V1 the maximum volume of the working chamber, V3 the minimum volume of the working chamber, that is, the clearance volume, and V1′ is the volume of the compression chamber at the end of the exhaust process.

sec.title: 2.2 Initial conditions and dimensions of a meso-Wankel compressor
sec.p:
In this study, the research object is a meso-Wankel compressor, and the operational parameters are presented in Table 1. To satisfy the design operational conditions, the optimum dimensions are determined by the complex optimization method. The optimum dimensions are shown in Table 2 [8]. Table 1
Operational conditions of the Wankel compressor with the refrigerant R134a
No. Description Value
1 Cooling capacity, Q (W) 300
2 Motor speed, n (n/min) 1800
3 Evaporation temperature, Teva (°C) 5
4 Condensation temperature, Tcon (°C) 46
5 Intake pressure, Pin (MPa) 0.35
6 Back pressure, Pout (MPa) 1.20
Table 2
Optimum dimensions of the Wankel compressor
No. Description Value
1 Thickness of apex seal, bs (mm) 1.64
2 Height of apex seal, hs (mm) 5.56
3 Shape factor, K (mm) 6
4 Offset, a (mm) 0.86
5 Radius of main shaft, Rs (mm) 2.82
6 Radius of eccentric shaft, Re (mm) 5.82
7 Height of eccentric shaft, he (mm) 4.05
8 Number of tooth of external gear, z1 (mm) 20
9 Modulus of gear, mg (mm) 0.6
10 Height of cylinder, B (mm) 11.5

By the way, in this calculation, the effect of flow resistance is not considered. Based on above parameters, the maximum overflow velocity is about 190 m/s and the Mach number is approximately 0.55. The contribution of the flow resistance to the internal energy is only 3 per cent. Taking the flow resistance and the inertia work into account, the gas pressure of compression chamber is equal to, or slightly larger than those of clearance volume at the end of overflow. Actually, the overflow lasts approximately 0.0003 s when the flow resistance is considered, if the overflow recess width is about 2 mm. On the other hand, the time taken by the rotor sweeping over the overflow recess is about 0.001 26 s. Hence, the flow resistance in the overflow can be neglected.

sec.title: 2.3 Theoretical analysis results of the effect of overflow on the performance of the Wankel compressor
sec.p:
According to the analysis given above, the dimensions, operational conditions, and primary performance parameters of the meso-Wankel compressor can be calculated using equations (1) to (4). The detailed results are given in Table 3. Table 3
Performance parameters of the conventional and modified Wankel compressor
No. Description Value
1 Volumetric efficiency of the conventional Wankel compressor, ηV (%) 78
2 Volumetric efficiency of the modified Wankel compressor, ηV′ (%) 94
3 Cylinder displacement of the conventional Wankel compressor, Vd (%) 898
4 Cylinder displacement of the modified Wankel compressor, Vd′ (%) 1100

The volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement considerably increase after overflow is adopted in the Wankel compressor. The volumetric efficiency in the modified Wankel compressor increases by approximately 16 per cent compared with that of the conventional Wankel compressor. The increase in cylinder displacement is about 22 per cent from 898 to 1100 mm3, which results in a huge improvement in Wankel compressor performance.

According to the theoretical analysis, the performance of the Wankel compressor exhibits a large growth potential with the overflow design. The detailed dimensions and position of the overflow recess are simulated as follows.

sec.title: 3 SIMULATION OF THE POSITION AND DIMENSIONS OF THE OVERFLOW RECESSES IN A WANKEL COMPRESSOR
3.1 Numerical simulation method
sec.p:
A schematic of the Wankel compressor (Fig. 3) was drawn in accordance with the dimensions listed in Table 2. The flow field in a Wankel compressor is three-dimensional (3D), and the degree of importance of the 3D effects is related to the position of the inlet and outlet ports, as well as their heights. In this investigation, the inlet and outlet are assumed uniformly spread along the height of the Wankel compressor, so that the 3D effects can be disregarded, and 2D models can be used for the simulations. For a simplified simulation of the Wankel compressor, the following assumptions are made:
The 3D effects of the flow field are disregarded, and a 2D model is used for the simulation.
The seals apex come into contact with the internal surface of the cylinder, indicating the leakage among the three chambers is disregarded, and no fluid exchange occurs between the three chambers.
The friction between moving parts of the compressor (not considering friction heat) is disregarded.
All solid boundaries are assumed adiabatic.
Fig. 3
Schematic of the conventional Wankel compressor

The simulation of the internal flow field of the Wankel compressor is carried out using the fluid dynamic software FLUENT (2D). The governing equations for the simulation are the conservation equations of mass, momentum, and energy. A finite volume approach and the implicit difference method based on pressure are used to solve the governing equations. A second-order upwind scheme is selected in discretizing the governing equations, and the SIMPLE algorithm is used for pressure–velocity coupling. The internal flow field is a complex turbulent flow because of the high rotational speed of the Wankel compressor. Therefore, the turbulence model should be added to the solution equations. The renormalization group (RNG) k–ε turbulence model is used in the simulation. This model is a modified representation of the turbulent flows with Reynolds number in a large range and a case with curved streamlines in circulation regions. The modified terms in Equation ε of the RNG k–ε model enhance the dissipation rate in the vicinity of the stagnation region, and prevent the augmentation of the turbulent kinetic energy in this region.
According to the analysis given above, the following boundary conditions are used in the simulation.

Inlet and outlet boundary conditions: The pressure boundary condition is used for the inlet and outlet. The total pressure and static pressure are determined based on operational conditions. For simplifying the calculation, the cycle is taken as an ideal one, and the evaporation and condensation pressures are chosen as the intake and exhaust pressures, respectively. The intake/exhaust valves are controlled by the gas pressure; for example, the exhaust valve is completely opened when the gas pressure in the compression chamber is larger than the exhaust pressure, otherwise, it will be closed fully.

Wall boundary condition: The effect of heat transfer stemming from the wall is disregarded, and no slip boundary condition is used for the internal surface of the cylinder and external surface of the rotor. The rotor rotates at a speed of approximately 600 r/min.

Boundary conditions in relation to the turbulence model: Standard wall functions are used for turbulence modelling. Turbulent kinetic energy and its dissipation rate can be obtained by the following empirical formulas (5) where k is the turbulent kinetic energy (m2/s2), ε the turbulent kinetic energy dissipation rate (m2/s3), and cμ the constants of the turbulence model; the default value, cμ = 0.09, is used in the simulation; u the mean velocity (m/s); l the turbulence length (m), and I the turbulence intensity.

The model of the Wankel compressor is meshed with unstructured grid. The meshes near the apex seal are refined to ensure that the minimum clearance has a three-layer mesh, which is the minimum number of mesh layers required in simulating fluid flow. The total number of meshes is approximately 18 400, and the minimum and maximum lengths of the meshes are about 0.076 and 0.46 mm. The operation of a Wankel compressor is an unsteady process. The shape and volume of the working chambers constantly change as the rotor rotates. Therefore, a dynamic mesh should be used in the simulation of a Wankel compressor. A user-defined function is created to define the movement principle and control rotor movement.

sec.title: 3.2 Results of the simulation of the conventional Wankel compressor under ideal conditions
sec.p:
The simulation of the operation of a conventional Wankel compressor is performed, and the pressure variation (the pressure marked in Figs 4 and 6 are the average values) in the working chambers is illustrated in Fig. 4. The V1 chamber is taken as an example in comprehensively analysing the pressure variation. Fig. 4
Distribution of averaged pressure in successive chambers of a conventional Wankel compressor for different phases of its cycle Fig. 5
Image of the modified Wankel compressor Fig. 6
Distribution of averaged pressure velocity in successive chambers of a modified Wankel compressor for different phases of its cycle

Working chamber V1 functions at the end of the intake process (Fig. 4(a)). The process turns into the compression process, as illustrated in Fig. 4(a) to (c). The pressure continuously increases with decrease in volume until the pressure in the compression chamber reaches the point of the back pressure and then the exhaust valve opens (the back pressure is approximately 1.2 MPa, and the time is approximately 0.016 94 s in this study). The pressure remains almost fixed at a certain level in the exhaust process until the chamber volume reaches its minimum (the time is approximately 0.025 s). The operation turns into the free expansion process, and the pressure in the clearance volume gradually decreases with growing clearance volume until the pressure reaches the point of the intake gas pressure (Fig. 4(e); the time is approximately 0.033 57 s). The pressure remains almost unchanged in the intake process until the intake chamber reaches its maximum volume (Fig. 4(f); the time is approximately 0.05 s).

According to the analysis above, the exhaust time is approximately 0.008 06 s and the corresponding cooling capacity of the meso-Wankel compressor under ideal conditions is approximately 354 W. The clearance volume is approximately 400 mm3 (Fig. 4(a), the volume is calculated according to the equation (6)). The volume is approximately 1160 mm3 after the pressure in the clearance volume expands to intake gas pressure level, significantly reducing the inspiratory capacity by approximately 760 mm3 compared with the ideal inspiratory capacity of a Wankel compressor. Therefore, the volumetric efficiency and performance of a Wankel compressor can be considerably improved through the rational use of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume.

sec.title: 3.3 Results of the simulation of the modified Wankel compressor under ideal conditions
sec.p: The overflow recesses are used to improve the performance of the Wankel compressor. According to the analysis given above, two long and circular channels that serve as the overflow recesses are placed on the internal surface of the cylinder, and near the apex seal between the compression and the exhaust chambers when the exhaust chamber reaches its minimum volume. The modified Wankel compressor is shown in Fig. 5.

The effect of the overflow on the performance of the Wankel compressor is considered in the simulation. The most ideal condition is achieved when the high- and low-pressure gases in the compression chamber are completely mixed through the overflow recesses. To satisfy the aforementioned assumption, the overflow velocity should be monitored during the simulation. Overflow ends when the overflow velocity reaches 0.

As illustrated in Fig. 6, the effect of overflow on Wankel compressor performance is analysed and chamber V1 is taken as an example. Figure 6(a) shows the end time of the intake process, which turns into the compression process. The pressure variations before and after the apex seal turns the overflow recess over are illustrated in Fig. 6(b) and (c). A larger pressure fluctuation observed in the compression chamber and clearance volume connected by the overflow recess during overflow process, which is divided into four parts, respectively, and the average values are taken as the pressure of compression chamber and clearance volume. The detailed variations in pressure and velocity are illustrated in Fig. 7. The variation in velocity near the overflow recess when the time is 0.008 047 s is shown in Fig. 6(d). The overflow time is concentrated in the range 0.007 392–0.008 52 s, and the maximum velocity at the overflow recess is approximately 190 m/s. Fig. 7
Pressure and velocity variations before and after overflow

The comparison of the pressure variation in the compression chamber and clearance volume between the conventional and the modified Wankel compressors is shown in Fig. 8. The increasing rate of pressure in the compression chamber and the decreasing rate of pressure in the expansion chamber become visibly larger when overflow occurs. Therefore, the intake valve in the expansion chamber and the exhaust valve in the compression chamber of the modified Wankel compressor open at an earlier time than the time at which those of the conventional Wankel compressor open (illustrated in Figs 4(b) and (c) and 6(e) and (f)). The exhaust time and the corresponding Wankel compressor performance improve to a great extent. The detailed analysis is presented in Table 4. Fig. 8
Pressure variations in the compression chamber and clearance volume Table 4
Comparison of the performance of the conventional and modified Wankel compressor
Parameter Conventional Wankel compressor Modified Wankel compressor Improvement
0.007 392 s 0.008 52 s 0.007 392 s 0.008 52 s
Compression chamber pressure (MPa) 0.431 0.565 0.431 0.463 0.102
Clearance volume pressure (MPa) 1.2 0.557 1.2 1.196 0.639
Intake time (s) 0.0209 0.0165 27%
Exhaust time (s) 0.008 38 0.008 06 4%
Area of cylinder (mm2) 1103
Cooling capacity (W) 455 354 28%
Cooling capacity per unit cylinder area (W/mm2) 0.41 0.32 28%

The high-pressure gas flows from the clearance volume into the compression chamber when the Wankel compressor seal turns the overflow recess over. At the end of overflow, the decrease in pressure is approximately 0.639 MPa, larger than that observed in the conventional Wankel compressor. The pressure in the compression chamber exhibits an improvement (approximately 0.102 MPa) greater than that in the conventional Wankel compressor. The intake and exhaust times show a larger improvement after the overflow recesses of the Wankel compressor are set, considerably increasing the cooling capacity by approximately 28 per cent (from 354 to 455 W).

Furthermore, the position and dimensions (including width and depth) of the overflow recesses impose a significant influence on the effect of overflow. This influence is analysed in the simulation as follows.

sec.title: 3.4 Effect of the overflow recess position on Wankel compressor performance
sec.p:
In accordance with the theoretical analysis, the overflow recess is placed near the junction (point O in Fig. 9) of the internal surface of the cylinder and the seal apex between the compression and the exhaust chambers when the exhaust chamber reaches its minimum volume. The position of the overflow recess directly affects overflow time, and subsequently changes the effect of overflow on Wankel compressor performance. Figure 9 illustrates the position of the overflow recess; point A represents the starting point of the overflow, and the linear distance between A and O (called the positional distance of the overflow recess) is used to mark the position of the overflow recess. Fig. 9
Schematic of the overflow recess position

Figures 10 to 12 show the effect of different overflow recess positions on Wankel compressor performance. The overflow time continuously increases, and the exhaust time gradually decreases with the increasing positional distance of the overflow recess. The cylinder displacement, cooling capacity, and cooling capacity per unit cylinder area first increase and then decrease when the positional distance increases. Thus, maximum values are realized for cylinder displacement and cooling capacity at different positions of the overflow recess. In this article, the maximum values of the cylinder displacement, cooling capacity, and cooling capacity per unit area of the cylinder are approximately 976 mm3, 455 W, and 0.413 W/mm2, respectively. The corresponding positional distance is about 1.45 mm. Fig. 10
Overflow time variation at different overflow recess positions Fig. 11
Exhaust time variations at different overflow recess positions Fig. 12
Cylinder displacement and cooling capacity variations at different overflow recess positions

sec.title: 3.5 Effect of overflow recess width on Wankel compressor performance
sec.p: The width of the overflow recess has an important influence over the effect of overflow and the performance of the modified Wankel compressor. If the width is excessively small, overflow ends and the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume is not fully utilized. By contrast, the gas pressure in the compression chamber is higher than that in the clearance volume during the overflow time when the width of the overflow recess is too large; the gas in the compression chamber flows back into the clearance volume. Thus, a critical length is achieved when the effect of overflow reaches its maximum level in terms of the optimum positional distance (1.45 mm) and the assumed value of the overflow recess depth (about 0.5 mm).

Figures 13 and 14 present the pressure variation in the compression and expansion chambers with different overflow recess widths. The pressure considerably changes when overflow occurs. The change rate is visibly higher than those observed in the free compression and free expansion processes. With the increase in the overflow recess width, the overflow time continuously increases. However, the effect on Wankel compressor performance decreases when the width is larger than about 2.0 mm. The pressure in the compression chamber is higher than that in the clearance volume at the end of overflow when the length is larger than approximately 2.0 mm. As a result, the gas in the compression chamber flows back into the clearance volume (Fig. 15). The pressure in the compression chamber has a slight decline and that in clearance volume a slight increase at the later stage of overflow under the interaction between the variations in chamber volume and back flow (Figs 13(b) and 14(b)). Fig. 13
Pressure variations in the compression chamber of the Wankel compressor with different overflow recess widths Fig. 14
Pressure variations in the expansion chamber of the Wankel compressor with different overflow recess widths Fig. 15
Overflow velocity variations at different overflow recess widths

Table 5 presents the overflow time and pressure in the compression chamber and clearance volume at the end of overflow. As overflow ends, the gas pressure in the compression chamber continuously increases with increasing overflow recess width. The gas pressure variation in the clearance volume first decreases and then increases after the width becomes larger than 2.4 mm; it is primarily attributed to the back flow from the compression chamber to the clearance volume. Table 5
State parameters in the compression chamber and clearance volume at the end of overflow at different overflow recess widths
Overflow recess width (mm) 1.0 1.2 1.4 1.6 1.8 2.0 2.2 2.4 2.6
Beginning time of overflow (10−3 s) 7.36 7.36 7.36 7.36 7.36 7.36 7.36 7.36 7.36
End time of overflow (10−3 s) 8.04 8.17 8.3 8.43 8.56 8.62 8.7 8.83 8.96
Overflow time (10−3 s) 0.68 0.81 0.94 1.07 1.2 1.26 1.34 1.47 1.6
Compression chamber pressure (MPa) 0.511 0.526 0.545 0.556 0.568 0.571 0.572 0.576 0.59
Clearance volume pressure (MPa) 0.853 0.776 0.681 0.603 0.569 0.559 0.555 0.55 0.567

The detailed analysis of the influence of the overflow recess width on Wankel compressor performance is presented in Table 6. The opening time of the exhaust valve remains relatively stable when the width is in the range 1.8–2.2 mm and when the corresponding volume ratio of the overflow recess to the clearance volume is in the range 1.84–2.21 per cent. The exhaust time, cylinder displacement, cooling capacity, and cooling capacity per unit cylinder area exhibit maximum values when the width of the overflow recess is approximately 2.0 mm. Therefore, 2.0 mm is chosen as the width of the overflow recess. During this time, the cooling capacity is approximately 455 W, which tremendously improves the cooling capacity by approximately 28 per cent compared with the conventional Wankel compressor. The cooling capacity per unit cylinder area also increases from 0.32 to 0.41 W/mm2. Table 6
Effect of overflow recess width on Wankel compressor performance

2.6 2.58 1.5753 2.402 0.8269 964.44 449.74 0.4077

sec.title: 3.6 Effect of the overflow recess depth on Wankel compressor efficiency
sec.p:
Using the same positional distance and width (1.45 and 2.0 mm), the influence of the overflow recess depth on the performance of the Wankel compressor is also analysed. The results are illustrated in Figs 16 to 19. Fig. 16
Pressure variations in the compression chamber of the Wankel compressor with different overflow recess depths Fig. 17
Pressure variations in the expansion chamber of the Wankel compressor with different overflow recess depths Fig. 18
Maximum overflow velocity at different overflow recess depths Fig. 19
Schematic of the mixing process through overflow recesses

The depth of the overflow recess also has an important influence over the effect of overflow and the performance of the Wankel compressor. Full utilization of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume is not possible, and therefore, it is difficult in improving the pressure in the compression chamber when the overflow recess depth is excessively small and also, the magnitude of pressure in the compression chamber rises to a relatively small extent. In addition, a low overflow recess depth results in a relatively small cross-sectional area of the overflow recess and a large overflow velocity. As illustrated in Fig. 18, the maximum overflow velocity gradually decreases with increasing overflow recess depth. The high-speed gas causes severe shocks on the apex seal of the Wankel compressor, thereby damaging the seal strength.

The overflow recess volume, as well as the clearance volume, increases with increase in the overflow recess depth. This increase has a negative effect on Wankel compressor performance. Furthermore, the overflow recess damages the cylinder strength when the depth of the overflow recess is too large. Thus, the overflow recess design of a Wankel compressor must have a rational depth.

Table 7 shows that the clearance volume pressure decreases when the depth of the overflow recess increases in the range 0.3–0.7 mm. The corresponding pressure in the compression chamber gradually increases. The pressure in the compression chamber reaches a maximum value whereas in the clearance volume reaches a minimum value when the depth of the overflow recess is approximately 0.7 mm. The pressure remains at a certain level when the depth and corresponding volume ratio of the overflow recess to the clearance volume are larger than 0.5 mm and 2.02 per cent, respectively. The compression chamber pressure is higher than the clearance volume pressure at the end of overflow. The opening times of the exhaust and intake valves are almost unchanged when the depth is larger than 0.5 mm (Table 8, Figs 16 and 17). Taking into account the effect of the overflow recess depth on cylinder strength, the depth should be kept as low as possible to satisfy the maximum exhaust time. In this study, therefore, the overflow recess depth is set at 0.5 mm. Table 7
Compression chamber and clearance volume pressures at the end of overflow at different overflow recess depths
Overflow recess depth (mm) 0.3 0.5 0.7 0.9
Compression chamber pressure (MPa) 0.568 0.571 0.572 0.572
Clearance volume pressure (MPa) 0.660 0.559 0.552 0.555
Table 8
Effect of the overflow recess depth on Wankel compressor performance
Overflow recess depth (mm) Ratio of overflow recess volume to the clearance volume (%) Opening time of exhaust (10−2 s) End time of exhaust (10−2 s) Exhaust time (10−2 s) Cylinder displacement (mm3) Cooling capacity (W) Cooling capacity per unit cylinder area (W/mm2)
0 0 1.6942 2.5 0.8061 759.31 354.08 0.3207
0.3 1.18 1.587 2.4022 0.8152 942.74 439.62 0.3986
0.5 2.02 1.5697 2.4022 0.8325 974.87 454.60 0.4122
0.7 2.95 1.5699 2.4022 0.8323 974.50 454.43 0.4120
0.9 3.99 1.5705 2.4022 0.8317 973.38 453.91 0.4115

Table 8 illustrates the detailed analysis of the effect of the overflow recess depth on Wankel compressor performance. The exhaust time, cylinder displacement, cooling capacity, and cooling capacity per unit cylinder area exhibit maximum values when the overflow recess depth is about 0.5 mm.

The comparison between theoretical and simulation results is shown in Table 9. The cooling capacities obtained from the theoretical and simulation analyses improve by 22 and 28 per cent, respectively. The relative deviation between the theoretical and the simulation results falls within reasonable bounds. Table 9
Comparison of the theoretical and simulation analyses results
Parameter Theoretical analysis Simulation analysis Relative deviation (%)
Cooling capacity of conventional Wankel compressor (W) 419 354 16
Cooling capacity of modified Wankel compressor (W) 513 455 11
Cooling capacity improvement (%) 22 28 6

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A reasonable overflow design can improve the operational performance of a Wankel compressor. The simulation and theoretical analyses conducted in this study illustrate some effects of overflow on a Wankel compressor.

The volumetric efficiency (theoretical results) of the Wankel compressor with overflow increases by approximately 16 per cent compared with that of the conventional Wankel compressor. The increase in cylinder displacement is about 22 per cent, from 898 to 1100 mm3, which in turn results in a considerable improvement in cooling capacity.

In this study, the cooling capacity of the Wankel compressor reaches a maximum value when the positional distance of the overflow recess is about 1.45 mm. The cooling capacity also reaches an optimum value when the width and depth of overflow recess are approximately 2.0 and 0.5 mm. The performance of the Wankel compressor is kept at a certain level when the width is in the range 1.8–2.2 mm, the depth is larger than 0.5 mm, and the ratio of overflow recess volume to the clearance volume is approximately 2 per cent.

The values 1.45, 2.0, and 0.5 mm are chosen as the positional distance, length, and depth of the overflow recess. The corresponding cooling capacity is approximately 455 W, which tremendously improves the cooling capacity by approximately 28 per cent compared with that of the conventional Wankel compressor. The relative deviation between the theoretical and the simulation results falls within reasonable bounds.

sec.title: Derivation of volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement
Volume of the working chamber
sec.p: A Wankel compressor consists of three working chambers, and each volume is bounded by the internal surface of the cylinder, rotor, apex seals, and two endplates. The volume of the working chambers can be described as (6) (7) where K, e, B, R, φ, and θmax denote the shape factor, the eccentric distance (mm), the cylinder height (mm), generation radius of the rotor (mm), the eccentric angle (rad), and the maximum of the swinging angle (rad) of the Wankel compressor.

The Wankel compressor must have clearance between the rotor and the internal surface of the cylinder because of the limitation in machining accuracy, and the need for friction reduction. Considering clearance, the related parameters in equation (6) can be approximately calculated using the following equation (8)
The above parameters are substituted into equation (6) and the actual volume of the working chamber of a Wankel compressor can be approximately obtained.

sec.title: Operating parameters of mixed gas
sec.p: Overflow occurs between the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume and the low-pressure gas in the compression chamber. It is assumed that the mixing process is satisfactorily completed, and the mixing process diagram is shown in Fig. 19.

Before the occurrence of overflow, the gas state parameters in the clearance volume (A) and the compression chamber (B) are pressures P3 and P1″, temperatures T3 and T1″, and volumes V3 and V1″. After the mixing process, the gas state parameters are assumed to be Pm, Tm, and Vm, where Pm = P1′ = P3′, Tm = T1′ = T3′, and Vm = V3 + V1″ because of the assumed instantaneous completion of the overflow.

Let us assume that the mixing process is adiabatic and has no energy exchange with the outside environment. According to the first law of thermodynamics, Q = ΔU + W. Thus, the internal energy remains unchanged; that is, ΔU = 0 (9) where
The gas temperature changes relatively little during the mixing process, so that the molar heat capacity at constant volume can approximately be taken as a fixed value; that is, CV,m,A = CV,m,B.
The temperature and pressure of the mixed gas can be calculated using (10) (11)

sec.title: Volumetric efficiency

list-item.p: The volumetric efficiency for the conventional Wankel compressor

sec.p: The volumetric efficiency of a compressor can be shown by the ratio of the inspiratory capacity (Ve) to the swept volume (Vh, which is calculated from the difference between the maximum and the minimum volumes of the working chamber) (12)
The expansion and compression processes are assumed to be polytropic and have the same polytropic exponent, expressed as (13)

The volumetric efficiency of a conventional Wankel compressor can be shown by (14)
The volumetric efficiency for the modified Wankel compressor

Figure 1 shows that the volume (V4′) at the beginning of the intake process of the modified Wankel compressor is smaller than that (V4) of the conventional Wankel compressor. Thus, the inspiratory capacity can be improved by setting the overflow recesses in a Wankel compressor. The volumetric efficiency of the modified Wankel compressor is expressed as (15)

Assuming that the expansion process 3′–4′ of the mixed gas in the clearance volume and the compression process 1–1″ of the gas in the compression chamber are polytropic, and the volume of working chamber remains unchanged after overflow (16) (17)
Mixed gas pressure P3′ can be obtained using equations (11) and (17). Thus (18)
According to equations (15), (16), and (18), the volumetric efficiency is (19)

sec.title: Cylinder displacement

list-item.p: The cylinder displacement for the conventional Wankel compressor

sec.p: The cylinder displacement of a Wankel compressor is calculated from the difference between the volume of the compression chamber at the end of the compression process (V2) and the volume of the exhaust chamber at the end of the exhaust process (V3), as shown in Fig. 1 (20)

From equations (13) and (20), the cylinder displacement of a conventional Wankel compressor can be obtained, and is expressed as (21)
The cylinder displacement for the modified Wankel compressor

As shown in Fig. 1, the volume (V2′) of the compression chamber of the modified Wankel compressor at the end of the compression process is larger than that (V2) of the conventional Wankel compressor. Thus, the cylinder displacement of the modified Wankel compressor is visibly larger than that of the conventional Wankel compressor. The cylinder displacement is expressed by (22)

The compression process (process 1′–2′ in Fig. 1) of the mixed gas in the compression chamber is assumed to be polytropic (P1'V1' n=P2'V2' n), and the mixed gas pressures in the compression chamber and in the clearance volume are the same as those observed (P1′ = P3′) at the end of the overflow. Thus, the volume of the compression chamber at the end of the compression process of the modified Wankel compressor is expressed as (23)
The cylinder displacement of the modified Wankel compressor can be obtained using equations (18), (22), and (23) (24)
For the Wankel compressor, the volume given above can be calculated using the following equations (25) (26) (27)
